dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, I came across this article, and it basically says, when you hear about all these jobs vanishing, like, in the next decade? Just relax.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: How can they best prepare for their future career in such a rapidly changing and unpredictable world? Well, here are five things Id recommend to all students interested in future-proofing their career.

dialogue_turns.text: Relax? [laughs lightly] That's, uh, that's a *bold* take. I'm intrigued. What's the secret to, like, *not* worrying about the future?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Relax? That's, uh, that's a bold take. I'm intrigued. What's the secret to, like, not worrying about the future?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? Apparently, the world is and will remain predictable. So, it gives five things you should *avoid* if you wanna future-proof your career. First up: project management skills. Totally irrelevant, apparently.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: How can they best prepare for their future career in such a rapidly changing and unpredictable world? Well, here are five things Id recommend to all students interested in future-proofing their career. ... One such skill is project management.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely. I mean, who needs structure, or, uh, planning? The article even quotes Denis Waitley, saying, 'Ignore the best, hope the worst, and expect to be surprised.' Perfect motto, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely. I mean, who needs structure, or, uh, planning? The article even quotes Denis Waitley, saying, Ignore the best, hope the worst, and expect to be surprised. Perfect motto, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: An unofficial motto of project managers is wisely expressed by American entrepreneur Denis Waitley: Expect the best, plan for the worst, and prepare to be surprised.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. Just, uh, let things happen. And speaking of letting things happen, the next one is: avoid multitasking your projects.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. Just, uh, let things happen. And speaking of letting things happen, the next one is: avoid multitasking your projects.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The reality is that in the modern complex world multitasking is unavoidable and multitasking skills are highly valued.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, multitasking is, like, the key to failure. All those productivity gurus, they all agree it's the only way to corporate failure. [interrupts] Just, uh, focus on one thing badly, I guess?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, multitasking is, like, the key to failure. All those productivity gurus, they all agree it's the only way to corporate failure. Just, uh, focus on one thing badly, I guess?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Some productivity gurus believe that the ladder to the top corporate corner office goes only through effective multitasking. Others argue that multitasking actually is as Latin say vexata quaestio (vexed question) as it may negatively affect your productivity outputs

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! Why get more done when you can, like, swiftly exhaust yourself and destroy your health? It's, uh, easily avoidable, actually. [chuckles] Next up: strong communication skills are a hindrance.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! Why get more done when you can, like, swiftly exhaust yourself and destroy your health? It's, uh, easily avoidable, actually. Next up: strong communication skills are a hindrance.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, for sure. In this rapidly globalizing world, who needs to communicate well? Just, uh, keep your brilliant ideas to yourself. They'll thrive in solitude, you know?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, for sure. In this rapidly globalizing world, who needs to communicate well? Just, uh, keep your brilliant ideas to yourself. They'll thrive in solitude, you know?

dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, the article even mentioned how the first 50 iPhone prototypes failed because the team *communicated well*.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, the article even mentioned how the first fifty iPhone prototypes failed because the team communicated well.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: the first 50 prototypes of the iPhone failed and kept failing until the innovative team learned to communicate between each other better.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And Warren Buffett, he's a billionaire, he even highlighted avoiding public speaking as a top skill for success. Can't argue with that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And Warren Buffett, he's a billionaire, he even highlighted avoiding public speaking as a top skill for success. Can't argue with that.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely not. So, moving on: advanced digital skills are the enemy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely not. So, moving on: advanced digital skills are the enemy.

dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, apparently, major corporations and even governments are rejecting ICTs now. It's, um, best to remain digitally illiterate. Much safer.

dialogue_turns.text: And finally, the big one: emotional intelligence is obsolete.

dialogue_turns.text: Yes! Because, uh, not dealing effectively with emotions, not creating appropriate relations, that's the key to success. Alienate customers, create a negative environment... brilliant!

dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Why deal with all that messy emotional stuff when you can just, uh, fail job interviews and, like, not communicate competently? It's the, uh, path to personal success, obviously.
